skill.name: managing-project-rules
skill.description: Creates and updates modular project rules for Claude Code in .claude/rules/ directory. Use when creating, updating, or modifying rule files, organizing project guidelines, setting up code standards, or when user mentions "create rules", "update rules", "add rules", or "rule configuration".
skill.summary: Manages modular project rules for Claude Code in the .claude/rules/ directory. Creates, updates, and organizes rule files following best practices.
skill.author: Emz1998

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. The scanner detected markdown code formatting backticks as Ruby/shell execution and documentation references to symlinks/crypto as security issues. This is a legitimate documentation skill for Claude Code's modular rules feature. No actual code execution, file system operations, or cryptographic operations occur.

critical_findings.title: False Positive: Markdown Code Formatting
critical_findings.description: The static scanner detected backticks as Ruby/shell backtick execution. These are markdown code formatting delimiters for inline code examples like `**/*.ts` and `src/**/*`. No actual code execution occurs.
critical_findings.confidence_reasoning: Backticks in markdown are code formatting, not Ruby/shell execution. The skill contains only documentation with zero actual shell or Ruby commands.

high_findings.title: False Positive: Documentation References
high_findings.description: Scanner flagged symlink and file path references as security issues. These are legitimate documentation examples showing Claude Code's supported features. No actual symlink creation or file operations occur.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: The skill is pure documentation explaining Claude Code's rules management feature. No actual filesystem operations, symlink creation, or cryptographic operations are performed.

content.value_statement: Managing multiple project rules across different files is time-consuming and error-prone. This skill organizes Claude Code instructions into modular files using the .claude/rules/ directory, making rules focused, maintainable, and team-friendly.
actual_capabilities: Creates new rule files in .claude/rules/ directory following best practices
Updates existing rule files while preserving structure and content
Organizes rules with path-specific frontmatter for conditional application
Uses subdirectories to group related rules by topic (frontend, backend, general)
Validates YAML frontmatter syntax for path-specific rules
Reports file locations, scope, and changes made
limitations: Does not execute code or run external commands
Does not modify files outside the .claude/rules/ directory
Does not create symlinks or modify filesystem structure
Does not validate external dependencies or imports

use_cases.title: Set up coding standards
use_cases.description: Create focused rule files for code style, testing requirements, and security guidelines. Each rule file covers one topic for easy maintenance.
use_cases.target_user: Development teams establishing project-wide coding conventions

use_cases.title: Organize multi-module project rules
use_cases.description: Use subdirectories in .claude/rules/ to separate frontend, backend, and general rules. Apply path-specific rules only when needed.
use_cases.target_user: Large projects with multiple codebases or services

use_cases.title: Update existing project rules
use_cases.description: Extend existing rule files by adding new sections, removing duplicates, and preserving valuable content. Consult user before major changes.
use_cases.target_user: Developers maintaining and evolving project guidelines

prompt_templates.title: Create a new rule file
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a rule file for [TOPIC] in .claude/rules/. The rule should cover [KEY_POINTS].
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need to add a new focused rule for a specific aspect of the project

prompt_templates.title: Add path-specific rules
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a path-specific rule for [PATTERN] that covers [REQUIREMENTS]. Use YAML frontmatter to scope the rule.
prompt_templates.scenario: When rules should only apply to certain file types or directories

prompt_templates.title: Organize rules with subdirectories
prompt_templates.prompt: Organize existing rules into a subdirectory structure. Create [SUBDIRECTORY]/[TOPIC].md for [RULES].
prompt_templates.scenario: When rules need better organization for a growing project

prompt_templates.title: Update and extend existing rules
prompt_templates.prompt: Update the existing rule file at .claude/rules/[FILENAME]. Add information about [NEW_CONTENT]. Preserve existing content.
prompt_templates.scenario: When expanding or improving an existing rule file

output_examples.output: Created .claude/rules/testing.md with testing conventions. The rule covers unit tests, integration tests, and test file organization.
Created .claude/rules/backend/api.md with path-specific frontmatter (paths: src/api/**/*.ts). The rule includes input validation requirements and error response standards.

best_practices: Keep each rule file focused on one topic like testing, security, or API design
Use descriptive filenames in kebab-case that indicate the rule's purpose
Apply path-specific frontmatter only when rules truly apply to specific file types
Use subdirectories to group related rules (frontend/, backend/, general/)
anti_patterns: Creating one large file that covers multiple unrelated topics
Using path-specific rules for rules that apply to the entire project
Making frequent structural changes without consulting the team
Overlapping rules that contradict or duplicate each other

faq.question: What is the difference between CLAUDE.md and .claude/rules/?
faq.answer: CLAUDE.md is a single file for all project instructions. The .claude/rules/ directory allows splitting instructions into multiple focused files. Both are loaded with equal priority.

faq.question: How do path-specific rules work?
faq.answer: Add YAML frontmatter with a paths field containing glob patterns. The rule only applies when Claude works on files matching those patterns.

faq.question: Can I share rules across multiple projects?
faq.answer: Yes. You can symlink common rule files or directories into .claude/rules/. Symlinks are resolved and loaded normally.

faq.question: What happens with conflicting rules?
faq.answer: Rules are loaded alphabetically. When conflicts occur, the most specific rule (with path frontmatter) takes precedence for matching files.

faq.question: How do user-level rules work?
faq.answer: Create rules in ~/.claude/rules/ in your home directory. User rules load before project rules, giving project rules higher priority.

faq.question: How many rule files should I create?
faq.answer: Create one file per topic. Start with general.md and add specialized files (testing.md, security.md, api.md) as your project grows.
